Aeropress]
The aero-press, designed by the inventor of the Aerobie Ring (a flying ring), is a great light-weight travel companion loved by many in the coffee world. It can be used with a paper or metal filter and combines emersion and pressure brewing resulting in a full-bodied and fragrent cup.
Load filter over cover and screw onto bottom-half of brewer, set on top of a cup or carafe.
Wet filter and warm brewer by pouring hot water into lower half.
Grind coffee on slightly finer grind than paper filter, dump hot water from carafe, positioning back under the brewer, and dump grounds into tube.>
Pour INT UNITS of water into brewer, filling to the top.
Using a spoon, stir grounds at bottom of brewer gently.
Slide top half of brewer in bottom half, initially in an angle, and then straighten out into a vertical position.
At 1:00 remove entire setup off of scale, and gently press using just body weight. Complete press should finish at 1:30.
Stir coffee in carafe and serve.
Frenchpress]
The french press is perhaps the easiest brew-method to achieve a good tasting cup of coffee. The method a full-emersion technique and filters through a metal screen. The method has the biggest body/mouth feel due to the high amount of sediment that passes through the screen; this also results in muted acidity and nuanced flavors.
Pour a small amount of hot water into the vessel to preheat.
Grind the coffee on a course/french press setting.
Pour out pre-heat water and dump in grounds.
Start timer and pour in INT grams of water.
With a spoon, stir wet grounds to fully expose to water.
Let sit for 30 seconds.
Last pour to finish at INT UNITS.
At 4:00 minutes, gently press plunger to completion.
Pour out all of coffee into cup or carraff to serve, leaving none left in the french press. Coffee left in the french press will continue to brew and could over extract.
